parts.text: But you know my name is Mina Stowey and I'm going
to have a conversation with Tom Monti four visible lives An Oral History
Project at the New York Public Library. Today is April
ninth and two thousand and fifteen. And this is being
recorded in Tom's beautiful apartment in Manhattan
on the West Side near the river.
Tom has a distinguished career as a composer
arranger keyboardist singer musicians
member of the Musicians Union Local eight o two as well as member of the
American Society of Composers Authors and Publishers. He's
a recording artist and he served as a musical director and he's
performed in places such as the Apollo Theater at the Philadelphia convention
center townhome in town hall New York City
. Manison Square Garden Cotton Club Broadway international Brooklyn
Academy of Music.
At the Village Vanguard the Village Gate SYMPHONY SPACE Rainbow
Room National Art Gallery and he was
also a guest artist at Carnegie Hall. In addition he
performed during a dinner party along with Tommy Keenan Twiggy at
Gracie Mansion for mayor cottage. Tom has
to be a in music from Long Island University in New York City and
his recordings are multiple
and he actually got the billboard award for best
song called at my best and now without further ado I'm
going to turn it over to Tom to tell us a
bit a bit about where you come from and what you would
like to say about yourself. Take it away. Tom thank you.
Well I come from Jamaica New Yorkers where I was born
I went to school boiled up in the Bronx which is
a parochial school.
So I took a year of music there.
My teacher is no longer with us.
So he he had passed on after that year
that I took up some piano lessons and later
on in high school I ended up taking up a
year of piano tuning and I wound up doing that. So
that's also my second trade and
several years later my wife was catering a party
for her brother and me. We
end up leaving somebody who said that the gentleman at the Metropolitan Opera
House needed piano tuners and he apprenticed me for five years
and he said you know you've got to be
twice as good or ten times better than everybody else because you're blind. People expect
you've got a great ear. Listen to what
I tell you and just do what I tell you. So you know he
he was my sensei as far as that is concerned or
for those who don't know what that means he was my mentor you know in
that. So that because of that you know a secondary trait which
is piano tuning music for the most
part I've been self-taught I did take a year or
class school and college and went to Long long versity
and. It was involved in the
Jazz Workshop. So.
I took some lessons with that with a
private guy for jazz and it was very informal you know he said to me I
would like to work on today and I would tell him
what things I was doing what it was working on and while I was performing
different things in bands and. Clubs and. Concert
halls in high schools and stuff like that and
. He would just help me out with different
techniques you know as far as how to play different things and make things go
smoother and well you know if you play things this way or that way you know I need to work so
hard you know just in terms of
positioning and you know all that positioning and fingering.
As far as the. Tuning goes.
A lot of the. A lot of the things that my boss at the Met said
you know came true. How do you
how do you go about working in the. Amount of time it
will take you to do a job and what will become second nature to you
. You know. Setting a temperament
you know all these different kinds of things that one needs to do
to you know rituals that you go through to tune a piano you know
you tune them inside an hour and a half to
go to somebodies house if you go in a recording studio you'll do it within
. Forty five minutes to an hour. You know many things
that. You learn here and perhaps things that you already

Gee. I would say that
That the tuning aspect I would say would probably
. Not have happened do you know had my wife and I met
